instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
threads.message: Hello. Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board here. No liquid damage, board looks perfectly fine, no corrosion at all and nothing getting hot. I get all voltages from page 84 up to <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR</SIGNAL>. From that down the list nothing is present. <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is reading low. It starts at 0.1V and goes slowly up to around 0.35V, jumps to 1V and goes back to 0.4V where it stabilizes. Looks like something is dragging it down. I'm suspecting bad PCH, but want to be sure before sending this back to costumer as I don't have proper equipment to replace that chip. Any hints?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
threads.message:
Check first diode mode to ground at L7630; compare with similar board.

Post <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> voltages; pins 3, 13, 14.
Check/replace R/<CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
threads.message:
Diode mode on L7630 gives me 0.074, unfortunately I don't have similar board to compare.


<CHIP>U7600</CHIP>:

Pin 3: 0.380V
Pin 13: 5.03V
Pin 14: 5.03V

<RESISTOR>R7630</RESISTOR> is 0 Ohms as expected
<CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR> is looking and measuring good with no shorts... Will replace it anyway

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
threads.message:
I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR> and now it's different. <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> stabilized at 1.05V but still no POST

<CHIP>U8180</CHIP>:

Pin 1 - 3.3V
Pin 2 - 3.3V
Pin 3 - 0V
Pin 4 - 3.3V
Pin 5 - 3.3V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
threads.message:
No need to check <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> anymore, once you've got steady <SIGNAL>1V05_S0</SIGNAL>.

Do you get voltage at L7430 and L7870?
Also check L7310.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
threads.message:
So you get even CPU core now.
Check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.message:
Pufff.
Do you get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, a pulse at least?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> In S0, No Power
threads.message: Somehow <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> solder was crappy. Reflowed it with a lot of flux and board worked again! Thanks for all the help. Can mark this one solved!
